Background:Yes, the long-term results of the Duhamel technique are superior to those of the transanal pull-through (TAPT) technique in terms of fecal continence and quality of life (QoL) for children with Hirschsprung disease (HD).

Therefore, based on this study, the Duhamel technique has shown better long-term outcomes in terms of fecal continence and QoL compared to the TAPT technique for the treatment of children with HD.

The transvaginal approach is used 39% of the time, transabdominal/transvesical approach is used 36% of the time, the laparoscopic/robotic approach is used to treat 15% of urogenital fistulas and a combination of transabdominal-transvaginal approach is used 3% of the time.

The results showed that both the QoL FCI impaired in patients who underwent surgery for correction HD, but the impairment in QoL was greater in patients who underw the TAP technique.

Percut surgery also been proven to be without resid deformities and recurrence after surgery.

It is for health professionals to consider these findings when choosing the most appropriate surg technique for their.

The advantages over open surgery are that percutaneous surgery is simpler, more straightforward and shorter concerning the duration.

is done according to the pivot maneuver the chances of incomplete release and damage to the digital nerve nearby will be increased.

The study used the Fecal Continence Index (FCI) questionnaire and the questionnaire for the Assessment of Quality of Life in Children and Adolescents with Fecal Incontinence (AQLCAFI) to evaluate the incidence of fecal incontinence and QoL in children with HD.

Background:Limitations of this study include lack of randomization, age difference between women in the intervention and comparison groups, lack of generalizability beyond the single health maintenance organization studied, and possible unmeasured confounders.

Knowledge of the importance of early cancer detection, receipt of a recommendation from a physician, younger age, and higher socioeconomic status are all associated with increased use of mammography (10).

In the postreminder implementation phase, women who received the intervention were 1.51 times more likely to undergo mammography than those in the comparison group (95% confidence interval [CI],1.40 – 1.62), after controlling for demographics and clinic visits.

In the prereminder phase, 63.4% of targeted women underwent mammography, compared with 75.4% in the postreminder implementation phase and 80.6% in the maintenance phases.

Using electronic medical record data, the investigators compared compliance with mammography during a prereminder phase (2004), a postreminder implementation phase (2006), and a postreminder maintenance phase (January 1 – July 1, 2007).

Beginning in 1993, the tri-annual interval was eliminated and women were invited for repeated screening every 1 or 2 years on the basis of the

July 14, 2009 — A multimodal reminder system can be both effectively implemented and maintained in a large health system and increase mammography rates, according to the results of a study reported online July 14 in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine.

Despite these benefits, however, a 1995 survey revealed that 30% of eligible U.S. women had not obtained a screening mammogram in the preceding 2 years (4).

The primary comparison group was women aged 42 to 49 years, for whom clinical guidelines also recommend mammography, who did not receive the reminder system intervention.

Women who have not undergone screening mammography within their recommended screening interval are identified by routine monthly computerized reviews of the Group Health Cooperative radiology information systems.

The study sample consisted of 35,104 women aged 42 years or older who were 20 months past their last mammogram (index date) and who were members of the Kaiser Permanente Northwest health maintenance organization.

Such factors as age, socioeconomic status, and physician recommendation have been associated with greater use of screening.

It has been suggested that fear of a false-positive result will “dissuade women from obtaining the life-saving benefits of mammography” (12).

The women identified by these reviews are mailed letters reminding them to schedule a clinical breast examination and screening mammography through a screening center.

Despite the mortality benefits of breast cancer screening, not all women receive regular mamm.
A randomized trial screening recommendation from the's primary care phys rather than from the director of the breast cancer screening center showed that methods had an equal effect (19).

Future studies should address practice-based factors that assist patients in completing mammograms within the context of a reminder program, as well as other factors that affect the reach and cost effectiveness of delivering the intervention to diverse patient groups in multiple settings."

The relation between a false-positive mammogram and the likelihood of adherence to screening in the next recommended interval was strongest among women who had not previously undergone mammography (odds ratio, 1.66 [CI, 1.26 to 2.17]).

These invitation letters summarize the woman's risk factors for breast cancer, inform women of their recommended screening interval, and are signed by the clinician in charge of the breast cancer screening center.

Background:Yes, double balloon enteroscopy (DBE) has been found to be efficacious and safe in a community setting.

Overall, the evidence suggests that DBE is an efficacious and safe procedure that can be successfully performed in a community setting.

The study found that the yield, efficacy, and complication rate of DBE in the community setting were comparable to those in a tertiary referral center.

The study reported that 44 antegrade and 44 retrograde DBEs were performed, with the mean time per antegrade DBE being 107.4±30.0 minutes and the mean time per lower DBE being 100.7±27.3 minutes.

This suggests that DBE can be successfully performed in a community setting for a variety of indications, including evaluation of anemia/gastrointestinal bleed, small bowel inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and dilation of strictures.

In the specific study mentioned, a total of 88 DBE procedures were performed on 66 patients in a community setting.

Research has shown that DBE performed in a community setting is equally as safe and effective as when it is performed in a tertiary referral center.

The diagnostic yield of DBE ranges between 43% and 83%, with a subsequent change in management for 57% to 84% of patients.

Lastly, intraoperative enteroscopy, in which the small bowel is "pleated" over an endoscope at laparotomy or laparoscopy, is the most accurate technique but has a significant complication rate.The disease mainly affects the proximal small bowel and decreases in severity distally and may spare the distal jejunum and ileum.

In this review, we will discuss the aetiology, current diagnostic approach and the therapeutic options available for managing patients with small bowel bleed.

Small bowel bleeding: a comprehensive review.

Another technique is double-balloon enteroscopy (DBE), which allows for the traversal of the entire small bowel using an enteroscope with an overtube.

The enteroscope is inserted by either the oral or anal route, so that therapeutic procedures can be carried out.12,14 General anesthesia is often required for this complex and prolonged technique.

In last decade, the availability of advanced diagnostic innovations like capsule endoscopy (CE), double-balloon enteroscopy (DBE) and computed tomography enterography has led to better understanding of the aetiological profile of small bowel bleeding and there is a paradigm shift in the management of small bowel bleeding, with the majority of cases now being treated non-surgically.

Capsule endoscopy and deep enteros have improved our ability to investigate small bowel bleeds.

Double-balloon enteroscopy (DBE), a technique that can traverse the whole of the small bowel using an enteroscope with an overtube, was first described in 2001.

 overall diagnostic yield is between 43% and 83%, with a subsequent change in management for 57% to 84% of patients.

that included 222 smallies, OGIB, at 66%, was the most common indication and angiodysplasia was the most common underlying lesion (50%) .

Endoscopic therapy in the form of electrocautery to ablate bleeding sources, biopsy, and dilation of Crohn's-related small bowel strictures was also performed in some cases.

In cases of difficult diagnosis, surgery and intra-operative enteroscopy can help with diagnosis and management.

If the source of GI bleeding is between the ampulla of Vater and the terminal ileum, it is designated as mid-GI bleeding [3, 4].

Background:This retrospective study aimed to analyze the 30-day mortality, age-related 30-day mortality, and 1-year mortality following emergency laparotomy, in order to encourage data collection, improve care, and establish best practices in this area.

Saunders DI, Murray D, Pichel AC, Varley S, Peden CJ, UK Emergency Laparotomy Network.

Despite being one of the most commonly performed emergency surgical procedures, there is a scarcity of data on the outcomes and postoperative mortality rates of emergency laparotomy.

The fundamental objective was an evidence-based identification of the factors determining survival and pattern of survival after emergency laparotomy.

Taking a similar approach, a unique global study of 1,409 children undergoing emergency laparotomy from 253 centres in 43 countries showed that adjusted mortality in children following surgery may be as high as 7 times greater in low-HDI and 

Yes, laparotomy during endovascular repair of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (REVAR) is associated with increased mortality.

Indeed, emergency laparotomy carries a high rate of mortality, with recent studies suggesting a 30-day mortality rate of 14-15%.

In this study the overall global mortality rate was 1·6 per cent at 24 hours (high 1·1 per cent, middle 1·9 per cent, low 3·4 per cent; P < 0·001), increasing to 5·4 per cent by 30 days (high 4·5 

Emergency laparotomy is considered as a high-risk procedure with significant postoperative morbidity and mortality.

Mortality and postoperative care after emergency laparotomy.

These results indicate that age is a significant factor in mortality following emergency laparotomy.

In conclusion, emergency laparotomy is associated with high mortality rates, particularly in patients over the age of 70.

This study aimed at creating data on survival pattern and various factors influencing mortality in patients who underwent emergency laparotomy in the department of general surgery of a tertiary care teaching hospital in Karnataka, India.

Variations in mortality after emergency laparotomy: The first report of the UK emergency laparotomy network.

This reaffirms the need for an optimized pattern of care in patients undergoing emergency laparotomy including multidisciplinary care to tackle immediate postoperative complications.

The overall 30-day mortality was found to be 23.84% (36/151).

The findings revealed that 30-day mortality was 12.4% in those under the age of 70, and 22% in those over the age of 70 (p<0.001).

Patient safety were suggested to play an important role, use of WHO Surgical Safety Checklist associated with reduced mortality at 30 days.

A descript retrospective study was conducted among 151 patients those who underwent emergency laparotomy in the Department of General Surgery Mysore Medical College and Research Institute, over a period of 8 months (January 01, 2016 – August 31, 2016).
